title: defaultTo should work on error as well

labels.name: issue bankruptcy
labels.description: Closing the issue/PR to start fresh

body:
I think It would really make sense for **defaultTo**  function to also make default if the first argument **isError**.

Many times you have some functions which you may not care if fail and that might be the reason you are making a default value for it.

e.x.
```javascript 
function doOrDie() {
    return new Error('I die') 
}
_.defaultTo(doOrDie(),"we don't care") 
```

maybe another useful example:
```javascript
let y = "aaa"
let x = _.defaultTo(_.attempt(JSON.parse,y),y)  // -> only if it was returning my string
```

title: simple filter functional (_.startsWith)
body:
Why these not working? 

```javascript 
let x = _.filter(["aaa","bbb"], _.startsWith("a"))
```

```javascript 
let x = _.filter(["aaa","bbb"], _.partial(_.startsWith,'a'))
```
I thought I would get `["aaa"]` but get empty `[]`

title: fp version of merge can't take merge more than two objects
body:
**Update**
Misread this issue actually, the problem appears to be that the `fp/merge` doesn't work as the normal `merge`, and can't merge more than two objects.

Original issue:

When merging more than two objects with the `merge from lodash/fp/merge`, overwriting `true` values is not possible with more than two objects. 

Steps to reproduce: 

```javascript
import merge from 'lodash/fp/merge';

merge( {foo: true}, {foo: false} ); // -> {foo: false}, works as expected, left to right merge overwrites the true value to false

merge( {foo: true}, {foo: true}, {foo: false} ) // -> {foo: true}, when the third parameter sets the value to false, it no longer overwrites it.
```

This is not an issue with the regular version of `merge`: 

```javascript
import merge from 'lodash/merge';

merge( {foo: true}, {foo: true}, {foo: false} ) // -> {foo: false}, works as expected
```

title: Remove outdated contributor tips
body:
The `opt-cli` pre-push functionality documented in the "tips" section of `CONTRIBUTING.md` was [removed in March 2016](https://github.com/lodash/lodash/commit/2cd12c38e32c76aca6396df617d79ac752d81935),
but the documentation encouraging contributors to use it still remains. Remove to avoid confusion for new contributors.

body:
Same as #5002 but for lodash v5 with test's fixes only.

By the way, is there any other reason why some test files (like `test/isFunction.js`) miss the `.test` suffix, except for the fact that there're faulty tests in them?

Because if I'll rename `test/isFunction.js` to `test/isFunction.test.js` I'll get an error in `should return 'true' for array view constructors` but it seems like it can be easily fixed with a simple `import { ..., root } from './utils.js'`. Or am I missing something? In case I do, I left its name unchanged and didn't `import { ...root }`

title: async gen support + wrong `isFunction` tests fixes

labels.name: issue bankruptcy
labels.description: Closing the issue/PR to start fresh

body:
Fixes #5001 

The issue already fixed on master (lodash v5) in cefddab1cab49189b2ff4d72acf8df7ec723dc22, with a much simpler check `typeof value === 'function'`. But I suppose that for backward compatibility reasons this wasn't done in v4. So I added missing `asyncGenTag === '[object AsyncGeneratorFunction]'`.

Also the tests:
1. `should return 'true' for async functions`
1. `should return 'true' for generator functions`
1. `should return 'true' for async generator functions`

checked nothing. As `asyncFunc` and `genFunc` were just normal functions. And checks like `typeof asyncFunc == 'function'` didn't catch this fact.

title: Added support for `BigInt64Array` and `BigUint64Array`.

labels.name: issue bankruptcy
labels.description: Closing the issue/PR to start fresh

body:
Fixes #4646 and #4998 

Some notes/questions:
1. I have a bit of doubt about the line https://github.com/anseal/lodash/blob/c663406d32ae6ce72bac2f84bb4cba55eb1f9761/test/test.js#L24284
The test `should create an object from the same realm as 'object'` obviously can't ever pass while it uses old `lodashStable` version of `isTypedArray`. So I changed it. But not totally sure if it's OK to change the test like I did.
1. I haven't changed test at https://github.com/lodash/lodash/blob/ded9bc66583ed0b4e3b7dc906206d40757b4a90a/vendor/underscore/test/objects.js#L797 as it seems like I'm not suppose to.
1. I haven't tested it in all environments (only in Node v14.15.1, Chrome 87, FF 83) but followed the general principle and think that everything, including tests, should work even in environments where `BigInt` is not supported.
1. There is also a follow up commit https://github.com/anseal/lodash/commit/17f9e12eaca42666248d12fe2995d394dc571c86  with changes in the test `should deep clone array/typed-array/plain-object source values` that prove `_.clone` works for `BigInt`. But there I had to switch from `lodashStable` to `_` also. And not sure if it's really needed, and if it is, if I should adapt it to check all `typedArrays`, not only `Uint8Array` and `BigUint64Array`

title: unsafe eval static analysis warning for all lodash packages

labels.name: issue bankruptcy
labels.description: Closing the issue/PR to start fresh

body:
The core lodash package falls back to a Function constructor when determining the `root` object here:

https://github.com/lodash/lodash/blob/898b378f069ecb6c92b7713529985ba78ff34d31/.internal/root.js#L10-L11

For folks working in privileged environments, like browser extensions, the use of a Function constructor throws static analysis warnings:

![Screen Shot 2020-11-23 at 12 26 11 PM](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/630449/100006022-16b92780-2d87-11eb-9631-e6829f12b5d0.png)

In our case, this warning triggers a manual review of our extension each time we submit a new version, even though the modern browsers we support will never fall back to the `Function` constructor. It would be great if there were a way for us to somehow not include this fallback.

Maybe instead of using a Function constructor, you could instead fall back to an [Immediately Invoked Function Expression](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Immediately_invoked_function_expression)? e.g.,

```javascript
const root = freeGlobalThis || freeGlobal || freeSelf || (function() { return this; })()
```

I believe this would accomplish the same thing without triggering warnings about CSP.

This ticket is similar to https://github.com/lodash/lodash/issues/4066 and https://github.com/lodash/lodash/issues/3328

title: Why does the map method not call baseMap? it only just call arrayMap?
body: When in runtime, we call _.map and pass a object parameter. But actually the _.map is a arrayMap method, it does not call the baseMap method.

title: Reflect prefixed map in uniqueId documentation

labels.name: issue bankruptcy
labels.description: Closing the issue/PR to start fresh

body:
This PR updates the documentation in `uniqueId()` to reflect the different counters used for each prefix by using clearly distinct numbers.

The current documentation implies that all prefixed IDs are incremented on the same counter, incrementing from `uniqueId('contact_'); // contact_104` to `uniqueId(); //105`. This behaviour was changed in #3644 with the introduction of the prefix map, and so this documentation could be misleading to users.

labels.name: issue bankruptcy

body:
Steps to reproduce

* Update the lodash version in lodash-cli tool
  ```sh
  cd ../lodash-cli
  vi package.json
  npm install
  cd -
  ```
* Run the lodash-cli tool with the proper exports flag
  ```sh
  node ../lodash-cli/bin/lodash modularize exports="es" -o ./
  ```

After merging this should be hopefully ready for `npm publish` in the `es` branch and tagged `4.17.20-es`.

title: _.sum does not return correct output for [null]
body:
`_.sum([1, null, 0])` and `_.sum([null, null])` returns expected values while `_.sum([null])` returns `null`.

```js
> _.sum([])
0
> _.sum()
0
> _.sum('a')
'a'
> _.sum(null)
0
> _.sum([1, null, 0])
1
> _.sum([null])
null <--- should be 0
> _.sum([null, null])
0
```

title: ES6 iterables

labels.name: issue bankruptcy
labels.description: Closing the issue/PR to start fresh

body:
ES6 provides a number of datastructures that are [iterable](https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/JavaScript/Guide/iterable). It would be nice if lodash supported these. This issue duplicates #737, as reactions can't be set on closed issues.

Let `a` and `b` be iterators yielding an infinite number of values, then:

```js
_.take(_.zip([...a], [...b]), 4) // never stops
_.take(_.zip(a, b), 4)           // is fine
```

title: zipObject does not preserve order
body:
Steps to reproduce:

```
const ids = [ 'pAAB6W', '7KK5BK', 'GaGPJ9', '866621' ];

const values = [
    { id: 'pAAB6W' },
    { id: '7KK5BK' },
    { id: 'GaGPJ9' },
    { id: '866621' },
];

console.log(zipObject(ids, values));
```

the output is:

```
{
    866621: { id: '866621' },
    pAAB6W: { id: 'pAAB6W' },
    7KK5BK: { id: '7KK5BK' },
    GaGPJ9: { id: 'GaGPJ9' },
}
```

but should be:

```
{
    pAAB6W: { id: 'pAAB6W' },
    7KK5BK: { id: '7KK5BK' },
    GaGPJ9: { id: 'GaGPJ9' },
    866621: { id: '866621' },
}
```

title: Missing UTF-8 meta tag causes lodash import to break in the browser
body:
I kept getting this error in the browser when importing Lodash's startCase method into my React project. ``` Uncaught SyntaxError: Invalid or unexpected token ``` For a little while I thought it was an issue with how I was processing it with Webpack. Finally, adding a meta tag to my `index.html` file fixed it. The stack trace seemed to point to some strange characters, which seems to support the idea that it was something to do with the charset. ``` <--------------
``` I'm not sure if this requires any action on the part of the maintainers but I hope that filing this issue might help someone else in the future.

title: `_.flip` doesn't preserve arity

labels.name: issue bankruptcy
labels.description: Closing the issue/PR to start fresh

body:
`_.flip`ed functions don't seem to preserve their arity for currying. The only way around this is to explicitly curry with `curryN`.

https://runkit.com/daedalus28/flip-arity

Here's the source of the runkit, embedded for good measure:
```js
let _ = require('lodash/fp')

let f = (x, y) => x + y
let g = _.curryN(2, _.flip(f))
let h = _.curry(_.flip(f))
g(1)(2) // works
h(1)(2) // explodes, h(...) is not a function
```

title: Can't build
body:
I tried forking the main repo and building branch `master` – no luck. I assume I'm doing something wrong, but I don't know what it is.

I'm doing this on a Windows 10 computer with WSL 2 installed. I did `npm install` and `npm run build` in both environments, with similar results. I didn't replicate both scenarios separately for this bug report – I'm using the same Windows folder, with `npm install` already ran, for the outputs below.

Windows PowerShell:
```
PS local-lodash-folder> npm run build

> lodash@5.0.0 build local-lodash-folder
> npm run build:main && npm run build:fp


> lodash@5.0.0 build:main local-lodash-folder
> node lib/main/build-dist.js

internal/modules/cjs/loader.js:969
  throw err;
  ^

Error: Cannot find module 'local-lodash-folder\lib\main\build-dist.js'
    at Function.Module._resolveFilename (internal/modules/cjs/loader.js:966:15)
    at Function.Module._load (internal/modules/cjs/loader.js:842:27)
    at Function.executeUserEntryPoint [as runMain] (internal/modules/run_main.js:71:12)
    at internal/main/run_main_module.js:17:47 {
  code: 'MODULE_NOT_FOUND',
  requireStack: []
}
```

Windows WSL:
```
bogdan@Bogdan-Home:local-lodash-folder$ npm run build

> lodash@5.0.0 build local-lodash-folder
> npm run build:main && npm run build:fp


> lodash@5.0.0 build:main local-lodash-folder
> node lib/main/build-dist.js

internal/modules/cjs/loader.js:638
    throw err;
    ^

Error: Cannot find module 'local-lodash-folder/lib/main/build-dist.js'
    at Function.Module._resolveFilename (internal/modules/cjs/loader.js:636:15)
    at Function.Module._load (internal/modules/cjs/loader.js:562:25)
    at Function.Module.runMain (internal/modules/cjs/loader.js:831:12)
    at startup (internal/bootstrap/node.js:283:19)
    at bootstrapNodeJSCore (internal/bootstrap/node.js:623:3)
```

What am I doing wrong?

body: https://github.com/lodash/lodash/blob/86a852fe763935bb64c12589df5391fd7d3bb14d/add.js#L6

title: Fix quality issues
body:
This pull request fixes some of the issues raised by [DeepSource](https://deepsource.io/gh/moulik-deepsource/lodash/) on my fork of this repo.

Some issues were automatically fixed by DeepSource.

This PR also contains a `.deepsource.toml`, which is used by the DeepSource to analyze your repository, in case you want to run continuous quality analyses on your repository. If you wish to do so, you can follow these steps:

- Merge this PR.
- Signup on DeepSource [here](https://deepsource.io/signup/).
- Activate analysis on your repo.

**If you don't want to use DeepSource, I can edit the PR to remove the `.deepsource.toml` file.**

title: TypeError: stack.get is not a function
body:
Occurs on lodash v4.17.20
## Code
```js
console.log(oldProfileConfig, newProfileConfig);
 if (!_.isEqual(oldProfileConfig, newProfileConfig)) {
  this.setProfileConfig(newProfileConfig);
}
```

## Log
```
{ onOffActive: false,
  onTime: 2020-10-01T09:00:00.000Z,
  offTime: 2020-09-30T21:00:00.000Z,
  dimSteps: [],
  scheduleDays: '1111111' } { onOffActive: false,
  onTime: 2020-10-01T09:00:00.000Z,
  offTime: 2020-09-30T21:00:00.000Z,
  dimSteps: [],
  scheduleDays: '1111111' }
[0-0] (node:14600) UnhandledPromiseRejectionWarning: TypeError: stack.get is not a function
    at equalObjects (/home/user/app/node_modules/lodash/core.js:1303:28)
    at baseIsEqualDeep (/home/user/app/node_modules/lodash/core.js:729:18)
    at baseIsEqual (/home/user/app/node_modules/lodash/core.js:664:12)
    at Function.isEqual (/home/user/app/node_modules/lodash/core.js:2660:12)
    at estimateCurrentScheduleDimLevel.then.dimLevel (/home/user/app/src/Devices/SmartLight/NASLightDevice.ts:642:24)
```

Can confirm issue resolved when downgrading to v4.17.19.
